title: 112_s1536
content: The Act is titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2011" or the "NOTICE Act of 2011". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act, titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2011" or the "NOTICE Act of 2011", defines key terms such as business entity, commerce, and consumer within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States. The curr_chunk defines terms related to telecommunications and wire communication, including customer service communication, telecommunication, and wire communication. The curr_chunk defines wire communication as the connection between points of origin and reception, including all facilities and services related to transmission. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location as required by SEC. 3. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, except if all employees are in the US or if the communication is initiated by a consumer to a foreign entity. Business entities are exempt from disclosing their physical location in customer service communications if the communication is initiated by the consumer, the employee is outside the US, and the consumer is aware of this. Emergency services and communications excluded by the Federal Trade Commission are also exempt from disclosure requirements. The Federal Trade Commission may exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from disclosure requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each year, participating business entities must certify compliance with disclosure requirements. The FTC will establish necessary regulations within a year of the Act's enactment, and the requirements apply to customer service communications after a specified date. After the enactment of this Act, customer service communications will be subject to disclosure requirements starting one year later. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 of the Act will be treated as a violation of FTC regulations on unfair or deceptive acts. The FTC has the power to prevent violations of the Act and its regulations, with penalties for non-compliance. The Act grants privileges and immunities under the Federal Trade Commission Act, preserving the authority of the FTC under other laws.
